questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: Match the following poison and site of action : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-1,B-2,C-3,D-4

 

The correct matches for the poisons and their primary sites of action, based on typical pharmacological effects, are:

 

Option A. Datura: Acts on the CNS (Central Nervous System) due to its content of tropane alkaloids which cause anticholinergic effects.

 

Option B. Nicotine: Primarily affects the cardiovascular system (CVS), influencing heart rate and blood pressure through its stimulant effects on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Option C. Nitric Acid: Its primary contact effect is on the skin, causing severe burns upon exposure.

 

Option D. Nux Vomica: Contains strychnine, which affects the spinal cord (spine), leading to heightened reflex excitability and convulsions.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • A-1: Datura acts on the CNS.
  • B-2: Nicotine affects the CVS.
  • C-3: Nitric Acid affects the Skin.
  • D-4: Nux Vomica acts on the Spine.

choices.text: Admit and give IV levofloxacin
Treat at home with oral Amox-clav
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone
Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.

 

In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage

 

Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.

 

Option C.  Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

choices.text: Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis
Repair with great saphenous vein graft
Repair with prosthetic graft
Repair with saphenous vein patch

questions.text: A man presented with a history of stab injury over the arm. On examination, there was a hematoma present, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5 cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which among the following is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

In this patient, who has sustained a long tear to the brachial artery due to a stab injury, the best treatment option is to repair it with a great saphenous vein interposition graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.

 

The most desirable graft used is the great saphenous vein. A native vein graft is preferable to a prosthetic graft because:

 

  • Its elastic properties are comparable to that of an artery and enable pulsatile flow.
  • The diameter is similar to that of an extremity artery.
  • It is not thrombogenic and has long-term patency.

 

Other grafts that can be used are cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits. However, the great saphenous vein is generally preferred due to better compatibility and long-term outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis can be done only if the repair is tension-free. If the length of the injured area is long, vessel injuries cannot be repaired by primary end-to-end anastomoses and instead require an interposition graft.

 

Option C. Prosthetic grafts: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when there has been trauma to the native saphenous vein or when there is a size mismatch. Polyetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used.

 

Option D. Saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used in the closure of the arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies and is not suitable for long tears.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For long arterial tears in trauma, such as a stab injury to the brachial artery, using a great saphenous vein graft for repair is preferred due to its compatibility with the native artery's diameter, elasticity, and non-thrombogenic properties.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis is experiencing three episodes of bleeding in stools per day but is otherwise stable. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid.

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, especially in a stable patient who is experiencing active symptoms like bleeding. It works as an anti-inflammatory agent in the colon and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-Fluorouracil: This is a chemotherapeutic agent and is not used for treating ulcerative colitis. It's primarily used in cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Budesonide: While budesonide, a corticosteroid, is used in ulcerative colitis, it's generally reserved for more severe cases or when 5-ASA is ineffective. In a stable patient, it may not be the first choice.

 

Option D. 6-Mercaptopurine: This is an immunosuppressant used in ulcerative colitis primarily for maintenance therapy or in patients who haven't responded to other treatments, not typically as a first-line treatment in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and is effective in reducing inflammation and maintaining remission in stable patients experiencing active symptoms.

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Button battery

 

Explanation:

 

The image you’ve provided shows a radiopaque object in the esophagus of a child, which is identified as a button battery.

 

On X-rays, button batteries typically present as small, circular objects with a double rim or halo effect. This is because they have a distinctive two-layer structure which shows up clearly on radiographs. The appearance in the X-ray  is characteristic of a button battery, with a clearly visible double rim. This is a medical emergency due to the risk of rapid and severe damage to the mucosal tissues from electrical discharge and leakage of caustic substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coin: Coins are also circular and radiopaque on X-rays but lack the double rim feature seen with button batteries. Coins tend to be uniform in density throughout. Although they are a common type of foreign body ingested by children, they generally pose less immediate danger compared to button batteries.

 

Option C. Ball: A small ball, depending on its material, might appear on an X-ray if it's dense enough. However, it would not typically show the structured double rim characteristic of a button battery.

 

Option D. Bottle Cap: Bottle caps may appear circular but would show irregular edges or threading and do not have the double rim appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate identification and removal of an ingested button battery are crucial due to the rapid damage that can occur. Emergency endoscopic retrieval is usually necessary to prevent severe injury or death.

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is intrinsically resistant to the given drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida krusei: Fluconazole

 

  • Candida krusei is known to have intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, which means that this organism generally does not respond to treatment with fluconazole. This is due to a combination of mechanisms including alterations in the target enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, efflux pump activity, and changes in membrane sterols. Therefore, for infections caused by Candida krusei, alternative antifungal agents such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole are typically considered.
  • In the clinical setting, the intrinsic resistance of Candida krusei to fluconazole is significant, as fluconazole is often used as a first-line agent for the treatment of Candida infections. The presence of Candida krusei may therefore necessitate a shift in the standard therapeutic approach and prompt the use of different antifungal therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus niger: Voriconazole Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against most species of Aspergillus, including Aspergillus niger. It is often used as a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Therefore, Aspergillus niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Micafungin Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin. Micafungin belongs to the echinocandin class of antifungal drugs, which are effective against most Aspergillus species, but echinocandins are not the first choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. They are typically used as second-line agents or in combination therapy for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option C. Candida glabrata: Amphotericin B Candida glabrata can be susceptible to amphotericin B, but it is known for having a dose-dependent sensitivity or a reduced susceptibility. Some strains may show resistance, but this is not considered intrinsic resistance. Instead, amphotericin B resistance in C. glabrata can be due to acquired mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, necessitating the use of alternative antifungal agents for treatment.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

Androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2 and 3) are responsible for non-scarring alopecia. On the other hand, frontal fibrosing alopecia falls under the category of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

 

  1. Alopecia areata 
    • It is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss.
    • The hair follicles are not destroyed and can regrow hair if the underlying inflammation is treated, thus it is considered non-scarring.
  2. Telogen effluvium 
    • It is a form of temporary hair loss that typically occurs after stress, a shock, or a traumatic event.
    • The hair loss is diffuse and does not involve scarring of the scalp.
  3. Androgenic alopecia
    • It is also known as male or female pattern baldness, is characterized by a progressive thinning of the hair in a typical pattern.
    • The condition is non-scarring as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner and shorter hairs but are not destroyed.
  4. FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA
    • Type of Hair Loss: Scarring alopecia primarily affecting the frontal hairline and eyebrows.
    • Predominantly Affects: Postmenopausal women.
    • Symptoms: Progressive hairline recession, eyebrow loss, and sometimes body hair loss.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Frontal Hairline Recession: Gradual and symmetrical.
      • Eyebrow Thinning: Outer third of eyebrows commonly affected.

 

 

  • Perifollicular Erythema: Redness around hair follicles.
  • Potential Causes: Autoimmune or hormonal factors may play a role.
  • Treatment:
    • Medical Approaches: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Cosmetic Solutions: Wigs, eyebrow makeup, tattoos.
  • Prognosis: Hair loss is often permanent; early intervention may slow progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia, which allows for the possibility of hair regrowth, includes alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is associated with scarring alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

choices.text: Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance
Stria albicans – Cushing syndrome
Xeroderma pigmentosum – Freckles
Café au lait spots – McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: An overweight 13-year-old girl has the following blackish discoloration on her neck, as shown in the image below. What is this condition and its association? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance

 

Option A.

 

Acanthosis Nigricans:

 

  • This condition is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically found in the intertriginous areas such as the neck, axilla, and groin.
  • The lesion’s appearance in the image is consistent with Acanthosis Nigricans.
  • It is commonly associated with insulin resistance and can be a marker for type 2 diabetes mellitus, especially in the context of overweight or obesity, as seen in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Striae Albicans:

 

  • This refers to the white or silver stretch marks that occur when the skin has been stretched rapidly as in the case of rapid weight gain or with conditions like Cushing syndrome.

 

 

  • However, the image does not show stretch marks but rather a hyperpigmented, thickened area of skin.

 

Option C. Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

 

 

  • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

 

Option D. Café au lait spots:

 

  • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome.

 

 

  • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Acanthosis Nigricans by its velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the neck and its association with insulin resistance in the context of obesity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with a history of depression has been treated with fluoxetine for the past six months. He presented to the emergency department with altered consciousness and an ECG showing QT prolongation, with a QTc of 447 ms. Recently, he was prescribed an additional medication for chronic pain management. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to his regimen that could have contributed to his current condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methadone

 

Methadone is known to cause QT prolongation and can interact with fluoxetine, which is an SSRI and inhibits CYP450 enzymes, particularly CYP2D6, that metabolize many drugs including methadone. The inhibition can increase methadone levels, thus increasing the risk of QT prolongation and potential torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piperidine is not a drug but rather a chemical class that includes various analgesics, such as fentanyl and its analogs. These medications do not typically cause QT prolongation; therefore, this would not be the likely cause of the patient's altered consciousness associated with QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Morphine is an opioid analgesic but is not commonly associated with QT prolongation. It is less likely to be the cause of the EKG changes in the scenario provided.

 

Option D. Tramadol is a centrally acting opioid analgesic, which also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. It can potentially interact with fluoxetine, leading to increased serotonin levels and risk of serotonin syndrome. While it is less commonly associated with QT prolongation compared to methadone, it can still pose a risk, especially when combined with other drugs that affect serotonin levels or when overdosed.

 

Based on the clinical history and QTc value provided, methadone is the most likely cause of QT prolongation in this scenario, making option (a) the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methadone can cause QT prolongation, and when combined with fluoxetine, which inhibits its metabolism, the risk of QT prolongation and related cardiac issues increases significantly.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca testis

 

  • Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is generally considered with extreme caution due to the high risk of recurrence and the limited availability of organs. However, certain exceptions exist based on the specific type of cancer and its overall prognosis and responsiveness to other treatments. Here's an analysis of the scenarios mentioned:

 

In rare cases, liver transplantation might be considered for metastatic testicular cancer if it is isolated to the liver and the primary cancer is under control. Testicular cancer tends to have a better overall prognosis compared to many other cancers due to its high responsiveness to chemotherapy. If the metastasis is limited and other treatments have been effective, liver transplantation could be a potential option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: Liver transplantation is not typically recommended for metastatic melanoma due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the likelihood of widespread metastasis. Melanoma is known to respond poorly to immunosuppression, which is a requisite part of post-transplant care.

 

Option B. Breast Cancer (Ca breast): Like melanoma, metastatic breast cancer is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation. Breast cancer can metastasize to multiple organs, and the post-transplant immunosuppression regime can exacerbate the spread and recurrence of the cancer.

 

Option D. Active Renal Cell Carcinoma (Active RCC): RCC is typically resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation, and like melanoma and breast cancer, is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation due to poor outcomes associated with the disease's aggressive nature and potential for widespread metastatic sites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

choices.text: Start ART after 2-3 weeks
Opening pressure will be normal
Start amphotericin monotherapy
80% of patients will have positive radiological findings

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with headache and neck stiffness. Fundoscopy revealed papilledema. India ink staining of the CSF showed an encapsulated organism. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start ART after 2-3 weeks

 

The clinical presentation and findings suggest cryptococcosis, and the causative organism is Cryptococcus neoformans. In HIV patients with Cryptococcus infection, it is important to delay the initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART) until 2-3 weeks after starting antifungal treatment. This delay is necessary to reduce the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), which can worsen the symptoms due to a strong immune response against the dying organisms.

 

Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes cryptococcal meningitis in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and sometimes photophobia. Papilledema can indicate raised intracranial pressure, a common complication of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Opening pressure will be normal: Incorrect. Raised intracranial pressure is common in cryptococcal meningitis, and lumbar puncture often reveals elevated opening pressures.

 

Option C. Start amphotericin monotherapy: Incorrect. The recommended initial treatment is a combination of amphotericin B and flucytosine, not monotherapy, for better efficacy and to reduce resistance.

 

Option D. 80% of patients will have positive radiological findings: Incorrect. Imaging like MRI or CT scan is not always reliable in diagnosing cryptococcal meningitis and may only show abnormalities in about 21-27% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with HIV who develop cryptococcal meningitis, ART should be delayed for 2-3 weeks after starting antifungal treatment to reduce the risk of IRIS, which could exacerbate clinical symptoms.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: Detoxification of Xenobiotics for phase 1 reaction (Hydroxylation) require monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 along with: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH

 

The detoxification of xenobiotics in phase 1 reactions, particularly hydroxylation reactions catalyzed by monooxygenases or cytochrome P-450 enzymes, requires reducing equivalents in the form of NADPH. NADPH serves as a cofactor that provides electrons for the enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NADH: NADH is not the primary cofactor used in phase 1 hydroxylation reactions.

 

Option C. FAD: FAD (Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide) is not typically involved in the hydroxylation reactions of xenobiotic detoxification in phase 1.

 

Option D. FADH2: Similar to FAD, FADH2 is not the primary cofactor required for the hydroxylation reactions involved in the detoxification of xenobiotics during phase 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this reaction, a xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor. The cytochrome P450 enzyme catalyzes this reaction, leading to the introduction of a hydroxyl group into the xenobiotic molecule, making it more water-soluble and facilitating subsequent conjugation reactions in phase 2 detoxification.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

choices.text: Oral hairy Leukoplakia

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

 

Option A:

 

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia:

 

  • This condition is characterized by a white, corrugated, "hairy" plaque typically found on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV.
  • The white membrane is not scrapeable, which helps to distinguish it from candidiasis.
  • The presence of this lesion in an immunocompromised patient that is non-scrapeable strongly indicates Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, which is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus:

 

  • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas, but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.

 

Option C. Lichen Sclerosus:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area, not the oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring, but it does not occur on the tongue.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Also known as oral thrush, candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 25.33

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

For a 60-year-old patient with diabetes and hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg), it is critical to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Current guidelines, including the 2023 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines, recommend initiating antihypertensive therapy in such patients due to the high risk of cardiovascular events. Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is an appropriate choice for initial antihypertensive therapy in diabetic patients. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is well-tolerated, without negatively impacting glycemic control. Ideally, an ACE inhibitor or ARB would be preferred, but if not available, a calcium channel blocker like amlodipine is a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not first-line therapy for hypertension unless there is a specific indication such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, or angina. Beta-blockers are not the preferred initial treatment for hypertensive diabetics.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modifications are important, they are insufficient alone for managing hypertension in a diabetic patient, who is at high cardiovascular risk.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not typically used as first-line therapy for hypertension. It may be used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but offers no additional advantage in this context and may cause orthostatic hypotension, worsening dizziness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

 

Ethionamide, a second-line antitubercular agent used in the treatment of MDR-TB, is known to cause hypothyroidism as a side effect. This condition is characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cycloserine: Cycloserine is used in the treatment of MDR-TB, but its side effects are more commonly neurological, including mood changes and seizures. It is not typically associated with thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is used in TB treatment and is known for its potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, rather than effects on thyroid function.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia but not typically hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left inferior phrenic vein

 

 

The left inferior phrenic vein is a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. Both the right and left inferior phrenic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left suprarenal vein: The left suprarenal vein does not drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Instead, it drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Left gonadal vein: Similar to the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (whether it is the testicular vein in males or the ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein before it reaches the inferior vena cava.

 

Option D. Right ascending lumbar vein: The right ascending lumbar vein is not a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. It usually joins with the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right side, which then drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tributaries of the inferior vena cava include veins that drain directly into it without first passing through another vein, except for the hepatic veins.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of heavy metal toxicity. Laboratory investigations confirm the presence of heavy metal ions in the patient's bloodstream. The medical team is considering chelation therapy to bind and facilitate the excretion of the toxic metals. Which of the following agents is NOT typically used for the treatment of heavy metal toxicity? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oximes

 

The agents listed are all chelating agents except for oximes, which are not typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

 

Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase that has been inactivated by organophosphate poisoning, not heavy metal toxicity. They do not have a chelating effect on heavy metals and are therefore not used in the treatment of heavy metal toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite): BAL is a chelating agent used to treat arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning. It works by binding to the heavy metal ions, forming a complex that can be excreted from the body.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is another chelating agent that binds to lead and other heavy metals. It is used in cases of lead poisoning and can also chelate other metals such as zinc, cadmium, and manganese.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is used in the treatment of copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, and can also chelate mercury and lead. It binds to the metals and helps remove them from the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oximes are not used for heavy metal chelation and are specifically used to treat organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase. Chelating agents like BAL, EDTA, and penicillamine are typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

choices.text: At least 80g dietary fibre
<5 g salt intake everyday
< 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: A diabetic patient's fasting blood glucose level is found to be 160 mg/dL. What will you advise the patient regarding non-pharmacological management? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 30% of the calories should come from fat

 

When advising a diabetic patient on non-pharmacological management, it is essential to focus on dietary and lifestyle modifications that can help control blood glucose levels and reduce cardiovascular risk.

 

It is advisable for less than 30% of daily caloric intake to come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and avoiding trans fats altogether. This recommendation helps in managing cholesterol levels and reducing cardiovascular risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At least 80g dietary fibre: The recommended daily intake of dietary fiber is 25 to 40 grams, not 80 grams. High fiber intake helps in controlling blood sugar levels.

 

Option B. <5 g salt intake everyday: The recommendation for sodium intake is less than 2.3 grams per day, with overall salt intake being less than 5 grams per day.

    

Option D. Cholesterol < 100g: There is no guideline recommending cholesterol intake to be less than 100 grams. Current guidelines focus more on overall fat intake and the types of fats consumed rather than specific cholesterol limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diabetic patients, it is recommended that less than 30% of daily calories come from fat, with saturated fat being less than 10% and trans fats being avoided. This helps in managing blood sugar levels and reducing cardiovascular risks.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

choices.text: Suicidal firearm wounds
Traumatic asphyxia
Drowning
Electrocution

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in all except: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Traumatic asphyxia

 

Option B. Traumatic Asphyxia : This condition typically results from a severe crush injury to the chest or abdomen that prevents normal respiration. Cadaveric spasms are less likely because the death does not involve a sudden catastrophic nervous system event that would induce immediate muscle contraction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Suicidal Firearm Wounds : Cadaveric spasm may occur in cases of suicidal firearm wounds due to the intense muscle contraction at the moment of death. The individual might be holding a weapon tightly, which can lead to a cadaveric spasm preserving the grip on the firearm.

 

Option C. Drowning : Cadaveric spasm can occur during drowning as the individual may be holding onto objects or vegetation in a panic, and these grips can become fixed due to the sudden cessation of brain function.

 

Option D. Electrocution : Electrocution can cause instantaneous and intense muscular contractions and possibly a cadaveric spasm. This can result in the deceased gripping onto any objects they were touching at the time of electrocution.

 

Educational objective :
