MR IM and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

questions.text: What is the schedule and route of administration of MR vaccine: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MR SC and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months

 

Option C : MR Sc and Oral Vitamin A at 9 months:

 

Explanation

 

This option is correct as per the National Immunization Schedule. The MR vaccine is given subcutaneously at 9 completed months along with the first dose of Vitamin A, aligning with the guidelines for both treatments.

 

Vitamin A Supplementation schedule

 

 

In total – 9 doses – 17 Lacs IU

 

Measles vaccine schedule

 

 

Educational objective :

 

The MR vaccine should be administered subcutaneously at 9 completed months, and the first dose of Vitamin A should be given concurrently. This regimen helps to ensure optimal immune response and nutritional support, which is crucial for preventing measles, rubella, and vitamin A deficiency-related health issues.

choices.text: ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67
ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

 

  • Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by hormone receptor positivity and low proliferation rates. The expression profile typically includes estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Additionally, this subtype is marked by a low Ki67 index, indicating a lower proliferation rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67: This combination, while similar in hormone receptor status, features a high Ki67 index, suggestive of a more aggressive subtype like Luminal B cancer.

 

Option C. ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67: This profile describes a HER2-positive and high-proliferation subtype (often seen in more aggressive breast cancers).

 

Option D. ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67: Known as triple-negative breast cancer, this profile is markedly different from Luminal A as it lacks expression of ER, PR, and HER2, and is associated with higher grade tumors.

 

Educational objective:

 

Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by positive hormone receptors (ER and PR), absence of HER2 expression, and low Ki67 levels, indicative of a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor that typically has a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.

questions.text:
When asked the patient to stand on left foot, right side went down. Which structures are involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2023)

 

 

 

  1. Superior gluteal nerve
  2. Gluteus minimus
  3. Gluteus medius
  4. Sciatic nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

 

 

This question describes a clinical scenario where a patient is exhibiting a positive Trendelenburg sign. When asked to stand on the left foot, the patient's right side drops, indicating a problem with the muscles or nerves responsible for maintaining hip stability. The Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

1. Superior Gluteal Nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to weakness in these muscles.

 

2. Gluteus Minimus: This muscle, along with the gluteus medius, helps to stabilize the pelvis during walking. Weakness or paralysis of the gluteus minimus results in the inability to maintain a level pelvis.

 

3. Gluteus Medius: This muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Weakness or paralysis causes the pelvis to drop on the side opposite to the stance leg.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve does not innervate the gluteus medius or minimus. Its primary functions involve the muscles of the posterior thigh and lower leg. Damage to the sciatic nerve would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side when standing on one foot, indicates weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by abnormal diastolic filling with relatively preserved systolic function. The histology often shows increased myocardial stiffness due to fibrosis, which is evident as diffuse fibrotic deposition within the myocardium. The cardiac muscle appears normal in size or slightly hypertrophic without significant dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Typically shows dilated heart chambers and significant myocardial thinning with fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided histology image.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Characterized by marked hypertrophy of the myocardium, especially the septum.

 

Option D. Atrial fibrillation: This is primarily an electrical disorder of the heart, typically not diagnosed via myocardial biopsy and does not have a distinctive histopathological appearance related to the rhythm disorder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.

 

High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Low transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Low transferrin saturation is indicative of inadequate iron within the body to fully saturate transferrin, which is the main protein in the blood that binds to iron and transports it throughout the body. This condition is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia, where there is a decreased level of total body iron.

 

Transferrin Saturation (%) = (Serum Iron / Total Iron-Binding Capacity) × 100

 

  • Normal: ~20–45%
  • Low: Indicates not enough iron bound to transferrin
  • High: Indicates excess circulating iron

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemochromatosis: Incorrect because this is characterized by increased iron levels in the body, typically leading to high transferrin saturation.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Incorrect because this is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, not primarily associated with iron deficiency.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrect as this anemia type is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low transferrin saturation is a significant marker for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia, reflecting a shortfall in available iron for red blood cell production.

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

 

Explanation:

 

For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan: This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.

 

Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here’s an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: A young male presents with suspected poisoning and has pin-point pupils. Which of the following can be the poison.  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opioid
 

 

Educational objective :

 

Pin-point pupils are a classic sign of opioid intoxication and are crucial for identifying opioid overdose in clinical settings. Opioids act by stimulating mu-receptors, leading to reduced sympathetic tone in the eye, which results in constricted pupils.

choices.text: Primary hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D toxicity
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is (INICET Nov 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignancy

 

Explanation:  

 

In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.

 

Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.

 

Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adolescents

 

Explanation

 

The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents. The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:

 

  1. Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  2. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  3. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  4. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  5. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  6. Suicide/Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.

 

Now Extended to become – HEEADSS

 

E – Eating and Exercise

 

S - Safety

 

Educational objective : The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. KIT    
  2. OCT 3
  3. PLAP
  4. HCG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

The classical markers of a seminoma include KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (also known as OCT3/4), and PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis and characterization of seminomas due to their high specificity.

 

1. KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is strongly expressed in seminomas, aiding in differentiation from other testicular neoplasms.

 

2. OCT 3 (OCT3/4): A transcription factor essential for maintaining the pluripotency of germ cells and expressed in seminomas, reflecting their embryonal origin.

 

3. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Frequently elevated in seminomas, this enzyme helps in confirming the germ cell origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

4. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Although some seminomas may express low levels of HCG, it is not considered a classical marker like the others, being more indicative of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

HCG may be present in ~15–20% of seminomas. However it is a classical marker for Choriocarcinoma (produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells)

 

Therefore, some seminomas can elevate serum hCG

 

However:

 

  • Not seen in all seminoma
  • More characteristic of choriocarcinoma and mixed germ cell tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

When diagnosing seminoma, clinicians should primarily focus on markers KIT, OCT3/4, and PLAP due to their high specificity and relevance to the germ cell lineage. HCG, although sometimes present, is not a classical marker for seminoma.

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

choices.text: OCP + Anti androgen
Counsel for metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: All the following are used for identification of a dead body except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nail

 

Less commonly used due to challenges in extracting sufficient DNA unless recent under-nail samples are available for identifying substances or DNA remnants.

 

Other Options:

 

The various tissues used for identification of a deceased individual vary in their utility and reliability.

 

Option A. Muscle: Can be used for DNA profiling, especially when other tissues are degraded.

 

Option B. Blood: Highly useful for DNA extraction and toxicological analysis to help in identification and determining cause of death.

 

Option D. Hair: Useful if the hair contains follicles; provides DNA which can be crucial for identification purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While nails can sometimes provide useful information, such as traces of substances the individual may have been in contact with, they are less reliable for DNA-based identification compared to other tissues like blood or hair with follicles.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy
  5. ECG
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

The patient presents with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar of 205 mg/dl), indicating diabetes. The appropriate investigations for a newly diagnosed diabetic patient are:

 

1. HbA1c: To assess long-term glycemic control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

2. Urine ACR (Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio): To screen for diabetic nephropathy, as microalbuminuria is an early sign of kidney damage.

 

4. Fundoscopy: To check for diabetic retinopathy and other microvascular changes in the eyes.

 

5. ECG: To screen for any cardiovascular complications, as diabetes increases the risk of heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Echocardiography: Not a routine screening test for diabetes unless there is a specific indication, such as suspected heart failure or structural heart disease.

 

6. Serum protein electrophoresis: Not indicated in the routine evaluation of diabetes and is used to diagnose conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IVIG

 

  • The constellation of symptoms described (fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling skin) is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. IVIG is a key component of the treatment for Kawasaki disease to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspirin: This is also a crucial part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease. Aspirin is used in Kawasaki disease to reduce inflammation and the risk of blood clot formation. However, it is often used in conjunction with IVIG.

 

Option C. Plenty of fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, fluid administration alone is not the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease. The use of IVIG and aspirin is more specific to address the underlying inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are antibiotics and are not the appropriate treatment for Kawasaki disease, which is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Fever + 4 out of 5 below = Classic Kawasaki

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are advantages of saline wet mount over iodine wet mount?

 

  1. Demonstration of motility of trophozoites
  2. Identify the internal structures of cysts
  3. Differentiate between bile and non-bile-stained eggs
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

 

The advantages of saline wet mount over iodine wet mount include its ability to demonstrate the motility of trophozoites and to differentiate between bile and non-bile-stained eggs.

 

  • Saline wet mount is an unstained preparation made using physiological saline, while iodine wet mount is prepared using diluted Lugol’s iodine or Dobell and O’Connor iodine solution.
  • Saline wet mount aids in visualizing the motility of trophozoites such as E. histolytica, Balantidium coli, and Giardia lamblia because it does not dry up as quickly as iodine wet mount.
  • It also helps differentiate between bile-stained and non-bile-stained eggs. Bile-stained eggs appear brown, while non-bile-stained eggs appear colorless. However, in iodine wet mounts, it is challenging to distinguish between bile-stained and non-bile-stained eggs because both appear stained brown.

 

Since iodine clearly stains the glycogen vacuoles and nuclei, the iodine wet mount helps in confirming the identification of cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Incorrect because iodine wet mount is better for identifying the internal structures of cysts due to its staining properties.

 

Option C. 2 and 3: Incorrect because saline wet mount does not effectively identify the internal structures of cysts compared to iodine wet mount.

 

Option D. 1, 2, and 3: Incorrect for the reasons mentioned above; statement 2 is not an advantage of the saline wet mount.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saline wet mounts are particularly useful for demonstrating the motility of trophozoites and differentiating between bile and non-bile-stained eggs.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Functional ovarian cyst
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

 

Nulliparity is associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian tumors, including borderline ovarian tumors, possibly due to uninterrupted ovulation and hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Functional ovarian cyst: Functional ovarian cysts typically do not progress to ovarian tumors.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has not been strongly linked with increased risk of borderline ovarian tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: Which drug is used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by daunorubicin? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexrazoxane

 

Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline chemotherapy agents like daunorubicin. It protects the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals that can damage cardiac tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: Aprepitant is utilized to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. It works as a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist but does not have a role in preventing cardiotoxicity from chemotherapeutic drugs.

 

Option C. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that offers protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy on normal tissues, particularly for kidneys and salivary glands, but it is not indicated for the prevention of cardiotoxicity from daunorubicin.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In oncology, it is often used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and to treat certain cancer-related conditions, but it is not used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane is specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by anthracycline chemotherapy agents such as daunorubicin by reducing free radical formation and oxidative stress on the heart.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

questions.text:
Consider the following Statements? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
  • Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
  • Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
  • Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

1. Contemplation: A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking. This statement correctly aligns with the contemplation phase where an individual acknowledges the problem and begins to think seriously about solving it soon but hasn’t committed to action yet.

 

3. Maintenance phase/determination phase: A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then. This is an accurate description of the maintenance phase, where the individual has made significant changes and is focused on maintaining these changes long-term. The use of "determination phase" here is non-standard; typically, it is just called "maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Precontemplation: A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health. This statement is incorrect for this phase. The precontemplation phase is characterized by a lack of awareness or denial of the problem, not considering changes. The correct description would be not considering the benefits or need for exercise.

 

4. Action phase: A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family. This statement incorrectly describes the action phase. The action phase involves active modification of behavior. This description instead suggests resignation or justification for inaction, which could fit the precontemplation or contemplation phase but is misaligned with the proactive nature of the action phase.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Behavior change – 6 stages –

 

Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome
Addison's disease

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with heart failure characterized by a reduced ejection fraction and low urine output. Which of the following anti-diabetic medications has been recently approved for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and may also improve diuresis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that not only improves glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes but also has cardiovascular benefits. Recent clinical trials have shown that empagliflozin is effective in reducing the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for heart failure in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), regardless of the presence or absence of diabetes. The diuretic effect of SGLT2 inhibitors, leading to increased urine output, may also contribute to the clinical benefit in heart failure patients by reducing fluid overload.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes, with no direct indication for heart failure.

 

Option C. Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that has been associated with fluid retention and is not indicated for patients with heart failure.

 

Option D. Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used to control high blood sugar in diabetes but does not have an indication for heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is approved for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and provides cardiovascular benefits, including increased diuresis, which can help manage fluid overload in heart failure patients.

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was started on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient was later found unconscious at home and brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient shows signs of arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation. Which of the following does NOT suggest TCA poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Hypothermia is NOT typically associated with TCA poisoning. In fact, hyperthermia may occur due to anticholinergic effects leading to decreased sweating and heat dissipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, primarily due to their anticholinergic, sodium channel-blocking, and alpha-adrenergic blocking effects. The key features in this case would be:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias:

 

  • TCAs block sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction delays, which can manifest as arrhythmias. They can also cause QT prolongation, predisposing to torsades de pointes.
  • Therefore, arrhythmias are a common and significant feature of TCA poisoning.

 

Option B. Confusion:

 

  • The anticholinergic effects of TCAs can lead to mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and even delirium.
  • Confusion is a typical presentation in TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Pupillary Dilation:

 

  • Anticholinergic effects also include pupillary dilation (mydriasis) due to paralysis of the iris sphincter muscle.
  • Pupillary dilation is often observed in TCA toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is not a typical feature of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning, whereas arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation are common clinical manifestations.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In the management of a thyroid storm, a critical and life-threatening condition due to an excess of thyroid hormone, a variety of medications are used to control the symptoms and the overactive thyroid. Which of the following drugs is not typically used in the treatment of thyroid storm? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is avoided in thyroid storm because it can displace thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially increasing the levels of active thyroid hormone in the blood and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options

 

Thyroid storm is a severe hypermetabolic state caused by an excessive release of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). The standard treatment includes:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used to manage the sympathetic symptoms of thyrotoxicosis like tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3.

 

Option B. Lugol’s Iodine: Lugol's Iodine is given to decrease the synthesis and release of thyroid hormones. The high iodine content temporarily inhibits the synthesis of thyroid hormones (the Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and blocks their release into the circulation.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is preferred for fever control in thyroid storm. It does not have the anti-inflammatory properties that might interfere with thyroid hormone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is not used in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Don’t give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Don’t give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

choices.text: To improve quality of life patient
Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To improve quality of life patient

 

Explanation:

 

Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.

 

The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient. It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To cure disease: This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.

 

Option B. Do nothing to prolong life: Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care: This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.

 

Educational Objective : 

 

Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

 

Bag and mask ventilation can be challenging and less effective in the presence of a scaphoid abdomen and mediastinal shift. In such cases, positive pressure ventilation through an endotracheal tube or a ventilator may be more appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 by mask: This is a valid intervention. Providing oxygen by mask can be an initial step to improve oxygenation in a neonate with respiratory distress. The goal is to support oxygenation until more definitive measures can be taken.

 

Option B. Positive pressure ventilation by ventilator: This is a valid intervention. Positive pressure ventilation with a ventilator may be necessary in cases of severe respiratory distress or failure. It helps to provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation to the neonate.

 

Option C. ET intubation: This is a valid intervention. Endotracheal (ET) intubation may be indicated in cases where positive pressure ventilation is required or to secure the airway in the presence of respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA
